Notes: Starting 11 October stay-at-home orders are being lifted in stages across NSW, Victoria, and part of Sydney. Schools will return to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. The remaining grades will return the week beginning 25 October.     Schools in areas where stay-at-home rules had been in place for an extended period of time (continuously from August 2021) will follow a staged return to on-site learning under Level 3 plus settings from 18 October.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018075601/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017214229/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/17/victoria-and-nsw-schools-are-reopening-amid-covid-outbreaks-what-can-be-learnt-from-overseas

Starting 11 October stay-at-home orders are being lifted in stages across NSW, Victoria, and part of Sydney. Schools will return to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. The remaining grades will return the week beginning 25 October.     Schools in areas where stay-at-home rules had been in place for an extended period of time (continuously from August 2021) will follow a staged return to on-site learning under Level 3 plus settings from 18 October.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211018075601/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017214229/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/17/victoria-and-nsw-schools-are-reopening-amid-covid-outbreaks-what-can-be-learnt-from-overseas

Starting 25 October schools of all grades have returned to face-to-face learning either through a âstaged returnâ or âfull returnâ, depending on health conditions in their area. Now in areas where 75% of the eligible population over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, students in kindergarten, years 1 and 12 return to in-person teaching. While in indoor settings in schools, masks or face coverings are required for all staff and all students in Year 7 and above. Masks are strongly recommended for primary students.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101171544/https://education.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/advice-for-families

On 11 October 2021 NSW opened and ended lockdown as the state passed the 70% double vaccination target. Workers in these regional areas who have received one vaccination dose will be permitted to return to their workplace from October 11 and will be given a grace period until November 1 to receive their second dose. Staff who work indoors must wear face masks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211015073454/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/business/rules  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018081943/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082938/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20211003_01.aspx    Currently Melbourne is still under lockdown (to end this Fri 22 Oct). Shopping is restricted to necessary goods and services (once per day, one person per household) and authorized work requires a permit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017235131/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082421/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/17/australias-melbourne-set-to-end-worlds-longest-lockdowns

Starting 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. Restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. Workplaces have opened with hygiene or capacity restrictions. Example: up to 75 per cent or up to 30 people can return if total workplace is 40 or less, if thereâs no more than 1 person per 4 square metres for Metropolitan Melbourne locations, and no more than 1 person per 2 square metres for Regional Victoria locations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210708181532/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184508/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/22/melbourne-covid-lockdown-ends-lifts-today-friday-victoria-end-lift-change-what-are-the-new-restrictions-rules-freedoms-reopening-plan  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

On 11 October 2021 NSW opened and ended lockdown as the state passed the 70% double vaccination target. Events can resume with 75% capacity and social distancing rules.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211018081943/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082938/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/Pages/20211003_01.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20211015073454/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/business/rules    Currently Melbourne is still under lockdown (to end this Fri 22 Oct). A stay-at-home curfew is in place for metropolitan Melbourne. Between 9:00pm and 5:00am, you cannot leave your home (or the home of your intimate partner or bubble buddy) other than for essential reasons. Shopping is restricted to necessary goods and services (once per day, one person per household) and authorized work requires a permit.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211017235131/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018082421/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/17/australias-melbourne-set-to-end-worlds-longest-lockdowns

Starting 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. However, music festivals still can't be held in NSW.   Other restrictions vary by region but generally are eased for people who are fully vaccinated or have a medical exemption. Generally indoor events have a capacity restriction of 75 per cent but outdoor events have 100 per cent capacity with social distancing. Example: A maximum of 2,000 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre assigned a specific seat â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. A maximum of 500 people can attend a controlled, ticketed outdoor event if theyâre allocated to a designated seating area â subject to 1 person per 2 square metres. Indoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 75 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises. Outdoor entertainment facilities can sell tickets for seated events at 100 per cent of fixed seating capacity or no more than 1 person per 2 square metres on the premises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307062444/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/entertainment-and-amusement-venues/nsw  https://web.archive.org/web/20210708181532/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/gatherings-and-work/vic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022184508/https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/oct/22/melbourne-covid-lockdown-ends-lifts-today-friday-victoria-end-lift-change-what-are-the-new-restrictions-rules-freedoms-reopening-plan  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022043759/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/easing-covid-19-restrictions/80-percent

Starting 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. Measures in Australia to limit the spread of COVID-19 vary by state and territory. Continuing policy in limited regions has canceled public transit routes or limited travel for essential work and essential purposes ex. within the Queensland/New South Wales border zone. NSW TrainLink still has ceased interstate services into Queensland. Travel across the border for recreation or social visits is not permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211022191007/https://transportnsw.info/covid-19/covid-19-safer-travel-guidance  https://web.archive.org/web/20211021174704/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/public-health-directions/travelling-to-queensland#border-zone-areas  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022183326/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new policy. Continuing, Australia has enacted a travel ban on all non-residents and non-Australian citizens entering Australia. From 23 July quarantine-free travel from New Zealand to Australia was (and remains) suspended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211007133620/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Starting 16 October a ban exception is travel from the North Island of New Zealand requires quarantine until at least 11:59pm on 31 October 2021. (It was previously banned).      Continuing policy is that Australiaâs borders are currently closed and entry to Australia remains strictly controlled to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Travel to Australia is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption. All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.      https://web.archive.org/web/20211022183326/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211022192716/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-international-travellers

Starting 1 Nov Australia's border open after 590 days of restricted access (since March 2020). Fully vaccinated travelers from New Zealand who test negative in pre-departure COVID tests can now enter Australia. They would be allowed to skip quarantine in certain jurisdictions like New South Wales, but those conditions may differ in other states and territories.    Continuing policy for other countries restricts travel to Australia is only available if you are exempt or you have been granted an individual exemption (even if you have been vaccinated). All travelers entering Australia from overseas will be quarantined in a hotel or designated facility for 14 days. Travelers are required to undertake their mandatory 14-day quarantine at their port of entry.       https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094008/https://au.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094556/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-travel-and-restrictions/international-travel-and-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102094513/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/01/australia-reopens-its-borders-to-new-zealand-and-singapore.html

No new policies. In areas of stay-at-home orders, you must carry a face mask with you at all times when you leave your home and wear a face mask when required. In areas where stay-at-home orders are easing masks remain mandatory for all indoor public venues, including public transport, front-of-house hospitality, retail and business premises, on planes and at airports. National policy recommends wearing a surgical mask when you are in the same room as the sick person. The sick person should also wear a mask when other people are in the same room.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004183442/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/rules/affected-area    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004184048/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-case-numbers-and-statistics

Starting 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. Restrictions vary by region but generally masks are required in certain public spaces. In Victoria you must wear a face mask whenever you leave your home in both indoor and outdoor settings. You must carry a mask at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211022194019/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/face-masks/vic    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004184048/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-case-numbers-and-statistics

Starting 29 Oct Regional Victoria and Metropolitan Melbourne are now under the same rules, and masks are no longer mandatory outdoors. You must wear a face mask in all indoor settings. Restrictions for the other regions vary by region but generally masks are required in certain public spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211102092302/https://www.healthdirect.gov.au/covid19-restriction-checker/face-masks/vic    https://web.archive.org/web/20211004184048/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-case-numbers-and-statistics

No new policy. Continuing from 10 June (published 19 June), the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) updated their advice for residential aged care facilities with special restrictions to remain in place for aged care facilities to protect older Australians.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210830085944/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/how-to-protect-yourself-and-others-from-coronavirus-covid-19/limits-on-public-gatherings-for-coronavirus-covid-19

Starting 22 Oct curfews and lockdowns have ended. National policy outlines recommended guidelines to protect the elderly along a three tiered system. The visitation restrictions and guidelines for residential aged care facilities follow social distancing, vaccination and COVID screening norms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210415104420/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/11/coronavirus-covid-19-national-aged-care-guidance-escalation-tiers-and-aged-care-provider-responses.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20211021011733/https://www.health.gov.au/node/18602/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-people-in-residential-aged-care-facilities-and-visitors

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting the closure of schools.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "With the consent of His Majesty the Sultan and Yang Di-Pertuan of Brunei Darussalam, it is hereby announced that the following control measures are reinstated for two weeks with immediate effect:    ...    3. Online learning will commenced for schools, other educational institutions, tuition classes, music classes and special needs classes."    Although it is initially unclear whether this directive applies to universities, Universiti Brunei Darussalam, the country's largest university, instituted Covid-19 shutdown measures on 9th August.    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See Universiti Brunei Darussalam (UBD)'s Covid-19 update page, archived at https://archive.vn/MKajg

No significant changes since the general tightening of measures on the 9th of August, except for the suspension of most in-patient dental procedures and services.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "ii) All officers and staff, whether government or private are required to do work-from-home. Only really needed staff are allowed to go out to work such as,    frontline workers (health sector, security sector, hospitality sector, transport sector)  daily necessities sector (food, retail business)  facilities and utilities sector (electricity, water, telecommunications)  officers at the borders and entrances to Brunei Darussalam  oil and gas and downstream sectors  development sector  agri-food and forestry sectors"    See the Ministry of Health's initial press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU  See the Ministry of Health's press release on dental procedures (dated 15th August), archived at https://archive.vn/BAxD8

No changes.    Measures were further tightened, after the discovery of more local cases on the 8th and 9th of August.    Per the press release of 09 Aug by the Ministry of Health, written in Malay,    "i) Any public gathering is not allowed. However, exceptions are allowed as follows:    A group of 15 people for funeral management (not COVID-19).  A group of 5 people for the marriage ceremony."    Additionally, "iii) Leaving the house without a significant purpose is not allowed. Only two people from one family are allowed out of the house to buy daily necessities."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/jK4EU

No change.    After local transmission cases were found in Brunei on 07 Aug in over a year, public transport capacity was reduced effective from 09 Aug.    Per the press release of 08 Aug by the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications, written in Malay,    "1.3.1 Public transport operators are limited to 50 per cent seating capacity in public transport vehicles."    See the Ministry of Transport and Infocommunications's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/dkRj1

This was shared by Minister at the Prime Ministerâs Office and Minister of Finance and Economy II Dato Seri Setia Dr Awang Haji Mohd Amin Liew bin Abdullah during a press conference yesterday, in addition to the strengthening of enforcement agenciesâ activities and public cooperation in aiding the government through the newly introduced 24-hour hotline, as well as involvement of penghulus and village heads in monitoring residents, which are important to ensure people reduce movement." No change. The only country-specific exception to the total travel ban is the Reciprocal Green Lane with Singapore, which has resumed with effect from 12th July (https://archive.vn/Eevqo). Other foreigners can only enter Brunei under specific essential travel circumstances (see below).    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 20 Oct, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Entry and Exit Requirements:        Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.          Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for the latest information.          Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Ministerâs Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/F1h1K  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office.          Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.      Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry?  Yes.          Visit the website of the Prime Ministerâs Office for more information regarding Bruneiâs pre-departure testing requirements.      Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry?  Yes.          Brunei International Airport implemented temperature screening requirements for all visitors. Temperature screening is also required at all land and sea-based points of entry into Brunei.      Extensions of social visits, professional visits, or business visits while already in Brunei can be made directly with the Visa, Visit and Diplomatic Section, Department of Immigration and National Registration.  Visit the website of the Department of Immigration and National Registration for more information.    ---    Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  â¢ Essential business travel (including official travel)  â¢ Students  â¢ Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  â¢ Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/knKd4  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf

No changes/deviation; Brunei continues to maintain a systematic, coordinated public campaign re: COVID.    The government continues to maintain an overall website where citizens can access any information related to COVID.   https://archive.vn/PwOIW    There is also an overall site on the Ministry of Health's website pertaining to Covid-19 vaccination (the programme, FAQ, public health messaging).  https://archive.vn/5UFPG    The Ministry of Health continues to update COVID case numbers daily (especially since the recent outbreak). See, for example, 19 Oct (https://archive.vn/V6p38) and 20 Oct (https://archive.vn/ws5EM).    No updates were missing.

No change.    As per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 20 Oct,    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Brunei?  Yes.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes.  Members of the public who need to undergo a swab test for any reason are advised to go to the Sports Complex, Raja Isteri Pengiran Anak Saleha (RIPAS) Hospital, or other health centers where testing is provided.  The testing fee for foreigners is BND $200 [sic, current cost as per Brunei's Ministry of Health is BND $50].  More information is available here.  Test results will be delivered through SMS.    See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/F1h1K  See the Ministry of Health press release on testing cost (22 May), archived at https://archive.vn/kU9pS

No changes.    On 07 August, Brunei detected its first local Covid-19 cases in over a year, all of which were unlinked to previously-known imported cases. Hence, Brunei has decided to tighten Covid measures, including instituting mandatory mask measures.    Per the press release of 07 Aug by the Ministry of Health,    "Meanwhile, to address the concerns on the spread of Delta variant around the world, including in Brunei Darussalam, the Ministry of Health would also like to inform the public on the changes in the face mask guidelines:    1. Face masks are required be worn at all times, especially indoors or in crowded places either indoor or outdoor.  2. Face mask must cover the wearer's nose and mouth.  3. This directive is applicable to all individuals regardless of their vaccination status."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated on 20 Oct,    "Face masks are mandatory at all times in all indoor and outdoor spaces."    See the Ministry of Health's press release, archived at https://archive.vn/C5fBL  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/F1h1K

Vaccination groups: Phase 1, 2 and 3 under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy  Phase 1: Frontline workers; senior citizens aged 60 and above; students studying abroad;  and  Phase 2: teachers; childcare centre staff/childcare workers; adults at high risk or suffering from chronic diseases  and  Phase 3: individuals aged 18 years and above    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV); Moderna (elasomeran/mRNA-1273)    Brunei's Phase 3 of its Vaccination Strategy, for individuals aged 18 years and above, commenced on 05 July. "[Individuals] who wish to get the COVID-19 vaccinations during Phase 3 are required to reserve a slot". No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." No change in policy since last iteration.    Additionally, under Brunei's Vaccination Strategy, senior citizens of age 60 and above belong to Phase 1, alongside Bruneians studying abroad and frontliners.    The advice for elderly people to be protected via vaccinations was reiterated on 07 Aug, when Brunei first detected its first local transmission cases in over a year. "Individuals who have not yet received COVID-19 vaccination especially those at high risk such as the elderly and those with chronic diseases are advised to reserve an vaccination slot as soon as possible. Walk-ins at vaccination centres will only be allowed for senior citizens aged 60 and above or individuals with special needs." The potential public health threat posed by COVID-19 is high, globally, nationally, and to our island. Individual risk is dependent on exposure. Everyone in our community can take steps now to prepare for this emerging public health threat by doing everyday preventative measures:     Itâs currently flu and respiratory disease season and CDC recommends getting a flu vaccine, taking everyday preventive actions to help stop the spread of germs, and taking flu antivirals if prescribed.  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. However, if soap and water are not readily available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol.  Avoid touching your mouth, eyes, and nose with unwashed hands.  Avoid close contact with people who are sick.  Practice proper cough etiquette â cover your mouth and nose with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects or surfaces.  Stay home when you are sick â do not go to work or school.    /web/20211108201920/https://www.grta.guam.gov/precautionary-measures-department-public-health

Guamâs PUA Weekly Benefit Amount (WBA) is $345 a week. Employees who have been laid off or furloughed due to COVID-19 qualify for the full amount. Employees still working but making less than $345 a week qualify for PUA minus their wages. Those making $345 or more do not qualify for PUA.

/web/20211108213047/https://guamrecovery.com/79-new-cases-46-hospitalized-community-reminded-to-continue-wearing-face-masks/     Covid-19 vaccines available, boosters available as below:   FREE COVID-19 BOOSTER VACCINATION VILLAGE CLINICS (for 65 and older) Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson  For individuals who received a Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna COVID-19 vaccine (first two doses), the following groups are eligible for a booster shot at 6 months or more after their initial series:    Anyone age 65 years and older  Anyone age 18 years and older with underlying medical conditions  Anyone 18 years and older with an elevated risk of COVID-19 exposure and transmission due to their occupation (e.g. healthcare workers, law enforcement, fire, K-12 teachers and support staff, university faculty, daycare employees, food and agriculture workers, manufacturing workers, USPS workers, corrections workers, public transit workers, grocery store workers) or institutional settings.  For individuals who received the Johnson and Johnson/Janssen COVID-19 vaccine, booster shots are also recommended for those who are 18 and older and who were vaccinated two or more months ago.

From October 13, 2021 the Indonesian government allows fully vaccinated international travellers from 19 countries to enter Bali and Riau Islands, including Bahrain, China, France, Hungary, India, Italy, Japan, Kuwait, Liechtenstein, New Zealand, Noway, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Spain, Sweden, and United Arab Emirates. Arrivals must have a valid visa or entry permit, a negative RT-PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, proof of hotel booking, and medical insurance of at least USD 100,000 covering COVID-19 treatment. Travellers must also quarantine for five days at their own expense.   Authorities have opened international borders at Hang Nadim International Airport (BTH), Juanda International Airport (SUB), Kualanamu International Airport (KNO), Ngurah Rai International Airport (DPS), Soekarno-Hatta International Airport (CGK), Sam Ratulangi International Airport (MDC), Yogyakarta International Airport (JOG), and seaports in Batam City, Riau Islands Province, and Nunukan Regency, North Kalimantan Province. Land cross-border posts are also open in Aruk and Entikong in West Kalimantan Province.  Source: Garda world     Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211023215200/https://www.imigrasi.go.id/id/2021/10/14/ini-daftar-19-negara-yang-warganya-dapat-memasuki-indonesia-melalui-bali-dan-kepri-sebagai-wisatawan/  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211022144200/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/536016/indonesia-authorities-extend-covid-19-restrictions-in-java-and-bali-through-at-least-nov-1-update-89      In the Circular Letter of the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs dated October 13, 2021, it is stated that since October 12, 2021, Indonesia has lifted the restrictions on entry to Indonesia for foreigners who have a history of travel from India within 14 days prior to arrival. Source: Indonesian directorate general of immigration website . No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and continues undergoing a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, restricting club activities with high risk of infection and suspension of all school excursions. Increased ventilation measures and distribution of antigen test kits will also continue to be conducted. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis.    There are recent examples of individual school closures as a result of outbreaks in Agano City, Niigata and Fukui City, Fukui.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023958/https://www.niikei.jp/227863/ (Agano City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017024018/https://www.fukui-tv.co.jp/?post_type=fukui_news&p=143499 (Fukui City)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (school measures)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

All precautionary measures have now been lifted in all prefectures.  Schools have all resumed in-person learning at full capacity due to measures being lifted. Schools are to continue undergoing stringent sanitation and infection prevention measures, increased ventilation measures, and distribute rapid antigen test kits. Students with illness symptoms are not to attend schools. Individual schools may also have the jurisdiction to close due to in-school outbreaks on a school-by-school basis. No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    All businesses including bars and nightclubs are able to reopen provided businesses serving alcohol receives a certificate of inspection for infection control by the Ministry of Health, however karaoke equipment is requested not to be used. During the precautionary period, all businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM.  Businesses are asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200827/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/0928eigo.pdf (Okinawa)

Remote working whenever possible continues to be encouraged by the federal government.    For all other prefectures, businesses are requested to operate at shortened business hours between 5:00AM to 9:00PM with alcohol permitted to being served 11:00AM to 8:00PM (in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, and Okinawa). In Tochigi, alcohol may be served until 7:30PM; and in Okinawa, acohol may be served until 7:00PM. Businesses have also been asked to reduce the number of workers in the office by 70% through utilizing remote methods of work and to request employees finish work by 8:00PM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017023524/https://corona.go.jp/emergency/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017222328/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013308261000.html (Hiroshima, Gifu, Fukuoka)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193347/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210929/k10013281591000.html (restrictions in Kanto region)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003193702/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20210928/k10013281561000.html (restrictions in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211003190552/https://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/_res/projects/default_project/_page_/001/015/636/20210928/torikumi.pdf (Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008200105/https://www.pref.okinawa.lg.jp/site/chijiko/koho/corona/documents/1007taishohousin.pdf (Okinawa)

No change to previous policy as Japan lifts emergency and priority measures for all prefectures and will undergo a precautionary period for one month. From Oct 1 to Oct 24, Tokyo will undergo a period with various lighter restrictions. For Okinawa, the precautionary period is between Oct 1 to Oct 31.    During the precautionary period, all events are asked to be completed by 9:00PM. For events involving loud events, capacity is limited to 50% of the venue capacity or an upper limit of 10,000 people. For events with no loud voices, 100% of the venue capacity may be used but not exceed an upper limit of 5,000 people. Border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism and other short-term purposes remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended.  For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Sep 27).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184357/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008204749/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100238774.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184616/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C129.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017184818/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

The government announces Japan will begin permitting entry of international students and shortening the quarantine period to 3-days for fully vaccinated individuals on business trips beginning November 8.    For all other non-residents, border closure for entry into Japan continues to be in place. Travel for tourism remain restricted, while all Visa-free travel is suspended. For travellers who are granted exceptional status for entry, various countries will have differing quarantine and testing requirements on arrival corresponding to country/region designation by variants of concern provided by the Japan Ministry of Foreign Affairs (latest list of specialty measures for regions is updated as of Nov 5).  To be eligible for a shortened quarantine period, Japan has so far designated only Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna as valid certificates of vaccination. All certificates must be issued by the public institution from government or country of origin, and must be written in either Japanese or English containing the following information: name, date of birth, vaccine name or manufacturer, vaccination date, dose. In addition, 14-days or more must have passed from the second dose date.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211106040544/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211105/k10013336361000.html (international students and business quarantine)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102001901/https://jp.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041148/https://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/files/100256050.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041201/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/info/pcwideareaspecificinfo_2021C138.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211106041008/https://www.anzen.mofa.go.jp/covid19/certificate_to_Japan.html

No change to previous policy. New unemployment subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1, p.34).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide financial support in the forms of: employment subsidies to encourage business owners to maintain employees, leave of absence due to COVID-19 infection, living expenses for leave of absence or the unemployed, and special support for low-income child-rearing households for a maximum of 50,000 yen per child. Employment subsidies have a maximum of 15,000 yen per day per person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017190441/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017190441/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205235/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy. New debt relief subsidy application deadlines for Nov 2021 to Dec 2021 have been set for February 28, 2022 (support document revised as of Oct 1).  The Japan Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare continues to provide debt relief: loans for small-lot emergency funds and comprehensive unemployment funds are provided at interest-free and payments may be deferred up to one year. Housing security loans are available for those at risk of losing housing: rent payments may be deferred up to 9-months with evidence of employment search. Property tax exemption may be available for applicants facing declining income or unemployment due to the pandemic. For single-parent households, family housing support loan of upto 40,000 yen for 12 months is available interest-free with the possibility of repayment exemption. Interviews for single-parent households will be conducted to understand their living conditions, motivation for employment, efforts to acquire qualifications, etc. A policy is also in place for the deferment for payments of national taxes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065100/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kurashiyashigoto.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211008205138/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000622924.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065132/https://corona.go.jp/action

No change to previous policy.  Antigen tests are limitedly available to eligible cluster cases when fast results are requested for a large number of people, e.g. schools. Typically due to potential inaccuracies, negative rapid antigen tests are re-tested via PCR.    PCR tests are conducted at medical institutions designated by prefectures for returnee patients, outpatients, and when a doctors deems the testing be necessary. In some areas, with the cooperation of regional medical associations, "regional outpatient/examination center" have been set up to carry out intensive examinations and to determine testing. While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigent testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017193602/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017193639/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017193929/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/

On Oct 15, as a result of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare approving the sale of rapid antigen testing for the general public nationwide, rapid antigen tests begin being sold in pharmacies. All purchasers are to sign a consent form with a pharmacist explaining the technology and in the case of a positive test, all individuals must seek medical attention from appropriate authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html

While symptomatic individuals are typically recommended, PCR testing can be made available at the discretion of certain institutions if a health centre or doctor determines an individual a close contact, even if asymptomatic. For PCR tests carried out at these institutions, patients will not be responsible for the cost of the tests. Patients however, are responsible for the initial consultation fee.    PCR tests, antigen tests, and antibody tests may be requested for asymptomatic individuals for the purposes of travel will however, be charged by laboratory facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211008192307/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211005/k10013291931000.html (rapid antigen testing in schools)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017225754/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211015/k10013309151000.html (rapid antigen tests in pharmacies)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065531/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/0000121431_00132.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065550/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/kenkou_iryou/dengue_fever_qa_00004.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023065600/https://jp.usembassy.gov/services/pcr-testing-facilities-in-japan/

No change to previous policy.  There is no evidence limitations for close contact tracing has fully resumed in Tokyo and Saitama. For many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017195316/https://www.m3.com/news/open/iryoishin/973681 (Tokyo wards)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201311/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/okinawa/20211014/5090015934.html (evidence of contact tracing in Okinawa)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201411/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/local/osaka/news/20211004-OYTNT50138/ (evidence of Hirakata, Osaka preparing for more streamlined contact tracing efforts in the event of a new wave)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201307/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy.  While infection rates continue to decrease in Tokyo, it was reported on Oct 20 that 60% of all cases in Tokyo are not traced and do not have known infection routes. Experts however urge the city to thoroughly investigate infection routes now that cases are low.  Early during the 5th wave, for many wards in Tokyo, close contact tracing has been overwhelmed and efforts have shifted to targeted/priority settings such as schools or elderly facilities and also have shifted focus in making sure those severely ill are properly traced.  For other prefectures, small-cluster contact tracing continues to be manually and comprehensively conducted, in addition to the utilization of the COVID-19 Contact-Confirming Application (COCOA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070133/https://mainichi.jp/articles/20211022/k00/00m/040/091000c (current contact tracing efforts in Tokyo)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823030440/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/national/20210821-OYT1T50023/ (Tokyo & Saitama contact tracing overwhelmed)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023070545/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/covid-19/kansenkakudaiboushi-iryouteikyou.html

No change to previous policy. The wearing of facial masks in Japan is wide spread and continues to be recommended by the government. No change to previous policy. Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231523/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017234602/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231042/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/

On Oct 15, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare will allow men in their teens and 20s to receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Those who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231042/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018003512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211013/k10013306041000.html

No change to previous policy.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    The Japanese government is also preparing to begin third dose vaccination for healthcare workers at the end of November at the earliest.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071253/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017231523/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071407/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018003512/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211013/k10013306041000.html (Pfizer for youth)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211023071137/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211020/k10013315151000.html (Pfizer for youth)

No change to previous policy.  Vaccination continues to be available and administered for all individuals age 12+ at the appropriate mass vaccination or muncipal vaccination sites.  Men in their teens and 20s to vaccinate may receive the Pfizer vaccine over concerns for myocarditis in response to guidelines from other countries. Young population who received Moderna for their first dose, may also mix vaccines and receive Pfizer for their second dose if they so choose.    Third dose inoculations are being prepared to be administered beginning December 2021. The priority for third dose vaccinations begin from the order of those who received their second doses 8 months prior (or more). The groups are as follows:  - Medical workers (first vaccinated in Feb) will be vaccinated from Dec.  - Elderly (first vaccinated in April) will be vaccinated from Jan 2022.  - Those with other priority inoculations including those with underlying illnesses.    In Osaka, Minami city, after calls for shortened business hours were lifted for restaurants on Oct 25, the city is testing out logistics for vaccination passports until Oct 29.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004111/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211101/k10013330171000.html (third dose)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004334/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211025/k10013321141000.html (vaccination passport in Minami)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003727/https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/special/coronavirus/vaccine/japan_2021/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102003759/https://www.fukushihoken.metro.tokyo.lg.jp/iryo/kansen/coronavaccine/daikibosesshu.html (Tokyo vaccination)  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102004155/https://osaka-mvc.com/ (Osaka vaccination)

No change to previous policy. Last report on provisional measures in nursing homes was published as of October 5, 2021.  The following preventative measures for the elderly continue to be conducted:  - Recommendations and communications for active/healthy living and staying indoors targeted towards senior citizens.  - Monthly evaluation of preventive and infection control measures within long-term care homes.  - Comprehensive information and training material for Long Term Care staff and ownership including donning/doffing of PPE, systematic area zoning within facilities, and procedures involving admissions, discharge, hygiene and garbage.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201732/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201817/https://www.mhlw.go.jp/stf/seisakunitsuite/bunya/hukushi_kaigo/kaigo_koureisha/taisakumatome_13635.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211017201826/http://kayoinoba.mhlw.go.jp/

Information about the vaccine programme in Myanmar is currently quite limited, and the wider political and security situation may affect any planned rollout. However it was previously noted:  THE Ministry of Health conducts vaccination programmes in respective regions/states for target populations. Starting 26 July 2021, the ministry used Sinopharm and Sinovac vaccines donated by China and purchased from China to vaccinate the public for the first injection. For the second dose, the ministry distributed the vaccines via land or with the help of Tatmadaw (Air) and MAI to the remote areas starting 21 August 2021.    The vaccines were allocated to Mon, Kayin, Ayeyawady, Bago, Taninthayi, Shan, Magway, Sagaing, Mandalay, Nay Pyi Taw, Kachin and Rakhine until 25 August 2021.    These vaccines were also used to vaccinate the factory workers in Yangon, Mandalay, Bago and Ayeyawady regions. â MNA    https://web.archive.org/web/20211011034946/https://www.mdn.gov.mm/index.php/en/covid-19-vaccines-distributed-nationwide-second-injections  https://archive.vn/xAeJD

A total of 24 groups have been identified and prioritized for vaccination in accordance with WHO guidance. These include different age groups of people, health staff, inmates from jails and custodies, persons with disabilities, members and families of ethnic armed organizations, people in IDP camps and students (12-18 years old)    Vaccines being given include Covishield, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Sputnik V and Covaxin    https://web.archive.org/web/20211108235830/https:/mohs.gov.mm/Main/content/publication/2019-ncov  https://drive.google.com/file/d/1MEA2xNRy0MwoMqkW04b6ykIyhSUJ8EBv/view?usp=sharing  (PLEASE DO NOT EDIT google doc)    https://web.archive.org/web/20211108064334/https:/www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/21/10/a23433636/myanmar-government-to-re-open-schools-revive-economy-and-support-currency-to-overcome-triple-crisi

In some regions schools will start reopening starting 8 November.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101213951/https://www.nst.com.my/news/nation/2021/10/739233/schools-johor-terengganu-reopen-phases-nov-8

Starting on 18 October, regions are either in Phase 3 or 4. The most stringent restrictions is : "All sectors can operate except those with high risk of transmission (e.g., spas,  pedicures and manicures, pubs and night clubs), subject to capacity limits and SOPs"    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101215501/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/laporan/PPN-en/National_Recovery_Plan_Report_28072021.pdf
"Live performances/events are not allowed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102011829/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/laporan/PPN-en/National_Recovery_Plan_Report_28072021.pdf

Not all social activities are allowed in regions still in phase 3, and there's a limit at 50% capacity for regions in phase 4.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102012215/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/index-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102011829/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/laporan/PPN-en/National_Recovery_Plan_Report_28072021.pdf

"3 people in a household may go out (non-fully vaccinated)" in phase 3 regions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102012215/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/index-en.html

Interstate travels for regions in phase 3 is not allowed    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102012215/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/kedah/index-en.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211102011829/https://pelanpemulihannegara.gov.my/laporan/PPN-en/National_Recovery_Plan_Report_28072021.pdf

Northland will move to alert level 2 on Oct 19  Parts of Waikato remain at Alert level 3   Auckland remains at step 1 of Alert level 3  The rest of New Zealand is at alert level 2    For level 3 children and young people should learn from home. Early learning centres can open to provide childcare for children whose parents need to go into work. Play centres and playgroups must close. All tertiary education providers should deliver their courses online.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011154448/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-3/

No change.     Northland is now at Alert Level 2. The rest of New Zealand is also at Alert Level 2, except for Auckland and parts of Waikato which are alert 3.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211101165440/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/alert-level-2/

Upper Northland - alert 3  Auckland - alert 3, step 1  Parts of Waikato - level 3, step 2  The rest of New Zealand is at Alert Level 2.     For level 3 children and young people should learn from home. Early learning centres can open to provide childcare for children whose parents need to go into work. Play centres and playgroups must close. All tertiary education providers should deliver their courses online.     http://web.archive.org/web/20211108142432/https://covid19.govt.nz/alert-levels-and-updates/current-alert-level/

Northland will move to alert level 2 on Oct 19  Parts of Waikato remain at Alert level 3   Auckland remains at step 1 of Alert level 3  The rest of New Zealand is at alert level 2    Level 3 - You should work from home if you can (Auckland, Northland and parts of Waikato). There is a pilot F2F project that will take from November 15th to 22nd December 2021. The F2F project will only apply to a limited number of schools.     Classes are openned depending on the level of alert in place. Currently under the strictest regulations (MECQ) applied, all classes are to be suspended. In other regions (GCQ and MGCQ) some classes are openned. Granular lockdowns in place in 83 areas across Metro Manila. The rest of the region remains at Alert Level 3, meaning that select establishments (ex religious venues, restaurants and personal care services) can remain open at 30% capacity for fully vaccinated individuals, or 50% capacity outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211018105009/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1156957

No change in policy.    "Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine (MECQ): The locations include Apayao, Kalinga, Batanes, Bulacan, Bataan, Cavite, Rizal, Laguna, and Naga City in Luzon; and Zamboanga City and Zamboanga del Norte in Mindanao through Oct. 31. Key sectors that may operate on-site at full capacity include health, financial institutions, energy, telecommunications, construction, manufacturing of essential goods, supermarkets, food establishments, and public transport, among others. All other establishments may operate at 50 percent capacity, though nonessential tourist attractions and entertainment venues like bars, clubs, casinos, and gyms are closed. "    link: https://archive.ph/za5KO

Under Level 4 alert: "The locations include Aurora, Bacolod City, Negros Oriental, and Davao Occidental. Residents aged below 18 or above 65 years old, as well as pregnant and immunocompromised people, must remain at home in all areas. Nonessential tourist attractions and entertainment venues are closed. Meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions (MICE) are not allowed. Non-essential social gatherings are banned. Food establishments may offer indoor and outdoor dine-in services at varying capacity limits; only fully vaccinated individuals can dine in. Businesses with the Safety Seal certification are allowed to operate at an additional 10 percent capacity."    link: https://archive.ph/MW7yT

Under the MECQ, the strictest restrictions currently in place, mass gatherings shall be prohibited. However those for the provision of critical government services and authorized humanitarian activities shal be allowed. religious gathering are limited to 5 persons.    Under the alert 4 level zones: social events such as but not limited to concerts and parties, wedding receptions, engagement parties, wedding anniversaries, debut and birthday parties, family reunions, and bridal or baby showers, parades, processions, motorcades, and gatherings at residences with any person outside of one's immediate household are prohibited.  Indoor venues for meetings, incentives, conferences, events (MICE) are prohibited. Indoor sports courts or venues, fitness studios, gyms, spas or other indoor leisure centers or facilities, and swimming pools are not allowed to operate.     Under the alert 4 level zones: Individual outdoor exercises shall be allowed for all ages regardless of comorbidities or vaccination status but shall be limited within the general area of their residence. Under the MECQ, the strictest restrictions in place, most gatherings are prohibited and religious services are limited to no more than 5 persons. Mass gatherings such as but not limited to, movie screenings, concerts, sporting events, and other entertainment activities, community assemblies, and non-essential work gatherings shall be prohibited. Gatherings that are for the provision of critical government services and authorized humanitarian activities while adhering to the prescribed minimum health standards shall be allowed.    Furthermore, under level 4: Social events such as but not limited to concerts and parties, wedding receptions, engagement parties, wedding anniversaries, debut and birthday parties, family reunions, and bridal or baby showers, parades, processions, motorcades, and gatherings at residences with any person outside of one's immediate household are prohibited. Outdoor or al fresco dine-in services in restaurants and eateries shall be allowed at a maximum of thirty percent (30%) venue/seating capacity regardless of vaccination status. Indoor dine-in services may be allowed at a limited ten (10%) venue/seating capacity but will cater only to individuals fully vaccinated against COVID-19 in addition to their allowed outdoor or al fresco capacity. Provided, that all workers/employees of these establishments have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19.  Provided further, that all workers/employees of these establishments are fully vaccinated against COVID-19. In-person religious gatherings shall be allowed at a maximum of thirty percent (30%) venue/seating capacity if conducted outdoors regardless of vaccination status. These gatherings may be allowed at a limited ten (10%) venue/seating capacity but may accommodate only individuals who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 in addition to their allowed outdoor capacities. Provided, that pastors, priests, rabbis, imams, or other religious ministers and the assistants of these religious congregations have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Gatherings for necrological services, wakes, inurnment, funerals for those who died of causes other than COVID-19 shall be allowed, provided that the same shall be limited to immediate family members, upon satisfactory proof of their relationship with the deceased and with full compliance with the prescribed minimum public health standards.    Guidelines for granular lockdown:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083254/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/static/resources/ECQ.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083328/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/static/resources/MECQ.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083412/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/static/resources/GCQ.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083704/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/static/resources/MGCQ.pdf    Updates of granular lockdown : http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083749/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fntfcovid19ph%2Fphotos%2Fa.104441587885110%2F402057558123510%2F%3Ftype%3D3%26theater    Guidelines for alerts level: http://web.archive.org/web/20211011085927/https://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/downloads/2021/09sep/20210913-Certified-Guidelines-for-Pilot-Areas.pdf  Updates of alerts level: http://web.archive.org/web/20211011083749/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fntfcovid19ph%2Fphotos%2Fa.104441587885110%2F402057558123510%2F%3Ftype%3D3%26theater

Under the MECQ, strictest regulations currently in place, public transport is suspended. However, point-to-point transport services provided by the government shall be allowed to operate, giving priority to healthcare worlers. While, commissioned shuttle services and personal vehicles of employees of permitted establishments are allowed, subject to guidelines provided by Dpt of Transportation. The movement of cargo vehicles shall be unhampered. Bikes and other non-motorized transportation are strongly encourages. Under the MECQ, strictest guidelines currently applied, strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households. Residents can only step out to access essential goods and services and work in permitted offices and establishments. The following people are not allowed to go outside: people below 21, people 60 and above, persons with disabilities and other health risks, pregnant women, any person who rside with the aforementioned.    Under the alert level 4 zones: The following persons shall not be allowed outside of their respective residences: (i) persons below eighteen (18) years old, (ii) those who are over sixty-five years (65) of age, (iii) those with immunodeficiencies, comorbidities, or other health risks, and (iv) pregnant women; provided, that they shall be allowed access to obtain essential goods and services, or for work in permitted industries and offices.    In Alert Level 3 zones: nightly curfew in place 00.00-04.00. Individual outdoor exercise is allowed; outdoor contact sports and indoor sports activities may take place at 30 percent capacity. Other indoor activities, like tourist attractions, meetings, conferences, exhibitions, social events, recreational venues, and personal care services may take place at 30 percent capacity. Businesses with Safety Seal certification may operate at an additional 10 percent capacity. Authorities allow all other businesses to operate at full capacity as long as they are not located within granular lockdown areas, but encourage companies to deploy minimal staff on-site and implement flexible work arrangements. Government agencies must operate with at least 30 percent on-site capacity while implementing telecommuting arrangements. No change in policy.    Under the MECQ, strictest guidelines currently applied, strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households. Residents can only step out to access essential goods and services and work in permitted offices and establishments. The following people are not allowed to go outside: people below 21, people 60 and above, persons with disabilities and other health risks, pregnant women, any person who rside with the aforementioned.    Under the alert level 4 zones: The following persons shall not be allowed outside of their respective residences: (i) persons below eighteen (18) years old, (ii) those who are over sixty-five years (65) of age, (iii) those with immunodeficiencies, comorbidities, or other health risks, and (iv) pregnant women; provided, that they shall be allowed access to obtain essential goods and services, or for work in permitted industries and offices.    In Alert Level 3 zones: nightly curfew in place 00.00-04.00. Individual outdoor exercise is allowed; outdoor contact sports and indoor sports activities may take place at 30 percent capacity. Other indoor activities, like tourist attractions, meetings, conferences, exhibitions, social events, recreational venues, and personal care services may take place at 30 percent capacity. Businesses with Safety Seal certification may operate at an additional 10 percent capacity. Authorities allow all other businesses to operate at full capacity as long as they are not located within granular lockdown areas, but encourage companies to deploy minimal staff on-site and implement flexible work arrangements. Government agencies must operate with at least 30 percent on-site capacity while implementing telecommuting arrangements.    link: https://archive.ph/za5KO

At present, in the Philippines only Filipinos, balikbayans, and foreigners holding valid and existing visas from green and yellow list countries are allowed entry in the Philippines.    Fully vaccinated individuals coming from either âGreenâ or âYellowâ List countries/territories/jurisdictions, need to undergo facility-based quarantine until the release of their negative Reverse Transcription - Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) testing taken on the fifth (5th) day. After which, they shall be required to undergo home quarantine until their tenth (10th) day, with the day of arrival being the first day.     Unvaccinated, partially vaccinated, or individuals whose vaccination status cannot be independently verified/confirmed by Philippine authorities as valid and authentic coming from either âGreenâ or âYellowâ List countries/territories/jurisdictions, shall be required to undergo facility-based quarantine until the release of their negative RT-PCR testing taken on the seventh (7th) day. After which, they shall be required to undergo home quarantine until their fourteenth (14th) day, with the day of arrival being the first day.     The inbound international travel of all persons, regardless of vaccination status, coming from or who have been to âRed Listâ countries/jurisdictions/territories to any port of the Philippines shall not be allowed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211011103654/https://dfa.gov.ph/covid-19-advisories/27995-public-advisory-dfa-reports-another-country-has-lifted-border-restriction-updates-infographics  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011104432/https://doh.gov.ph/sites/default/files/health-update/IATFResolution142.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20211011104707/https://www.santaferelo.com/en/mobility-insights/news-and-blog/immigration-update-philippines-updated-list-of-green-and-red-countries/

The IATF has adopted âYellowâ and âRedâ classifications in addition to âGreenâ for countries/territories/jurisdictions based on their respective COVID-19 incidence rates and case counts.  Passengers coming from, or who have been to, âRedâ jurisdictions will NOT be allowed entry to the Philippines.     And the only country on the read list is "Latvia".    link: https://archive.ph/THPre  link: https://archive.ph/aZRK2
